Actually this is a common issue. Deciding at what point 2 variations on an organism are different species. You hear it a lot, that x animal has 2 new species. Not as in we discovered new ones, but actually we just subdivided what were used to thinking of as 1 species. The recent one i can think of is giraffes. We now know there are actually 4 different species of giraffe, whereas until recently it was just a giraffe is a giraffe.

Wow, I wish people would stop calling this plant by a stupid made up name "Cats Ear." This plant was considered a vegetable like modern Spinach by my ancestors in Italy and Greece and would you believe it, it actually had names in the languages they spoke. Thanks for mentioning that it's edible, but your video is overdramatized and doesn't mention that many of our ancestors ate this nutritious food and even cultivated it to stay alive and that might be one of the reasons we are alive today, and also that it can grow in gravel with no dirt and no fertilizer and very little water making it a food crop that can grow in areas not considered farmable? I ate this plant and talked about it in one of my most recent videos, for all of the above reasons. I even told the story of the time I was picking it and dandelions and some kind lady had to warn me that what I was picking was not a dandelion, in my video.

Dandelion's have a job to do: help loosen up impacted soils, inject calcium into the soils, even out acidity in the soils. Once these 3 things are done, they die out & don't return! (Unless they're needed again.)
They lock in nutrients for other plants, they're good for pollinators, they look pretty, and they're edible! Who decided these are weeds?

Great video, very informative!  However, because native plants are disappearing everywhere, in large part due to being out-competed by plant species from other places/countries (both of these flowers are non-native to N. America), and partly because many gardeners don't know enough about their own natives. Plants endemic to an area support native pollinators best, so we would recommend planting and supporting plant species that can act as host plants for moths and butterflies as well as provide floral resources to bees. :-) Perhaps you would consider creating one of your wonderful segments on this topic.

Suggestion for future video: tarweeds! They are also in the sunflower family and they use their sticky hairs to trap and kill "carrion" insects, whose corpses attract beneficial predators that then kill the caterpillars that would otherwise eat the tarweeds: https://www.miridae.com/s/2018-lopresti_krimmel_pearse.pdf

Plus, they are closely related to the Hawaiian silverswords - which at first glance look nothing like them. And they are really beautiful in my opinion. There are tons of species in the Bay Area too!

Anyways, thank you Deep Look for the amazing botanical videos <3

Little known thing about the dandelion is that it's a pioneer plant species. And as is the case with all pioneer plants they are most successful when the conditions for more permanent growth is not ideal. They lock nutrients into the ground. So they are very good plants to have from a long term perspective. Once ground nutrients and PH is normalised other plants easily out-compete them.
A mowed lawn is akin to a grazed meadow. However of course dandelions are the first thing to be grazed. So basically with a lawn your best bet is to mow regularly enough so that flowers and seeds can never form. However it is worth noting that dandelions are very good for your lawn too if you can live with them. They will only take over if your soil is really poor.
In most cases you can sample your soil to determine deficiencies that you can nudge into a better range through fertilisers. Your other plants then have a chance to out-compete them.
But dandelions are good for soil. No mess. No fertiliser runoff. No fuss. And I find them to be a particularly fetching plant as well.

Since I love eating dandelion leaves, I sowed lots of dandelion seeds in the shadier parts of my lawn...under large shrubs where grass doesn't like to grow. When grown in semi-shaded, dandelion leaves grow big and tender...and are less tough and bitter than those grown in full sun, so they are best for eating raw.

I also have cat's ears in my lawn, but never knew that they were also edible. I'll have to try them and see if I like them as much as dandelions. But regardless,I will give them a special place in my garden since pollinators love them.
